hedline.hl1: Wired Glasses Called eShades Offer Floating-Web Trick

abstract.p: Inviso's eShades, a head-mounted computer display device, looks like a pair of oversize sunglasses but offers a display that has appearance of a 19-inch monitor seen from a distance of two and a half feet; photo (S)

block.p: So far, wearable computing has been for the highly technical and the very strange. But Inviso, a company with headquarters in Sunnyvale, Calif., would like to change that with eShades, a head-mounted computer display device that looks like a pair of oversize sunglasses.
When attached to a laptop, the eShades device makes it possible to view documents or Web pages at what appears to be full size.

So far, wearable computing has been for the highly technical and the very strange. But Inviso, a company with headquarters in Sunnyvale, Calif., would like to change that with eShades, a head-mounted computer display device that looks like a pair of oversize sunglasses.
When attached to a laptop, the eShades device makes it possible to view documents or Web pages at what appears to be full size.

The glasses use a technology called Liquid Crystal on Silicon. Liquid crystal is injected under a glass pane that is placed over a silicon chip. The result is a flat-panel display on the computer chip itself.

When viewed with the optics in the eShades, the display has the appearance of a 19-inch monitor seen from a distance of two and a half feet. But the resolution, 800 by 600 pixels, is closer to what you might find on a 15-inch conventional monitor.

The company expects to have the glasses available early next year at a price between $550 and $600. They are aimed at mobile professionals who value their privacy while working. It will also appeal to those who value battery life: Inviso says the eShades will use only about a quarter of the power of conventional laptop displays.
